examples.description: Given a UK Limited Company which was started on 2019-01-01 -> And the company is Invoice accounting for VAT, not on the FRS -> And the current date is 2019-11-30 -> And it is VAT registered from 2019-01-01 -> And its first accounting year ends on 2019-12-31 -> And it has a contact in United Kingdom named John Smith set to always charge VAT -> And the contact has organisation name 'Acme' -> And the company has the following bills: -> Given its VAT status changes to de-registered with an effective de-registration date of 2019-03-31 -> And the company filed its latest vat return -> And the company re-registered for VAT from 2019-06-01 on the Invoice basis, not on the FRS, with a pre-registration period of 6 months -> Then the company ledger entries for 818 (VAT reclaimed) are:
examples.full_description: Pre-registration periods that overlap previous registrations First registration is within 6 months of second registration, and pre-reg date is set as 6 months. #we actually set the pre-reg to start the day after the de-registration date of the first registration Given a UK Limited Company which was started on 2019-01-01 -> And the company is Invoice accounting for VAT, not on the FRS -> And the current date is 2019-11-30 -> And it is VAT registered from 2019-01-01 -> And its first accounting year ends on 2019-12-31 -> And it has a contact in United Kingdom named John Smith set to always charge VAT -> And the contact has organisation name 'Acme' -> And the company has the following bills: -> Given its VAT status changes to de-registered with an effective de-registration date of 2019-03-31 -> And the company filed its latest vat return -> And the company re-registered for VAT from 2019-06-01 on the Invoice basis, not on the FRS, with a pre-registration period of 6 months -> Then the company ledger entries for 818 (VAT reclaimed) are:

examples.description: Given a UK Limited Company which was started on 2019-01-01 -> And the company is Invoice accounting for VAT, not on the FRS -> And the current date is 2019-11-30 -> And it is VAT registered from 2019-01-01 -> And its first accounting year ends on 2019-12-31 -> And it has a contact in United Kingdom named John Smith set to always charge VAT -> And the contact has organisation name 'Acme' -> And the company has the following bills: -> Given its VAT status changes to de-registered with an effective de-registration date of 2019-03-31 -> And the company filed its latest vat return -> And the company re-registered for VAT from 2019-11-01 on the Invoice basis, not on the FRS, with a pre-registration period of 6 months -> Then the company ledger entries for 818 (VAT reclaimed) are:
examples.full_description: Pre-registration periods that overlap previous registrations First registration over 6 months before second registration, pre-reg is set as 6 months and post first registration bill over 6 months before second registration Given a UK Limited Company which was started on 2019-01-01 -> And the company is Invoice accounting for VAT, not on the FRS -> And the current date is 2019-11-30 -> And it is VAT registered from 2019-01-01 -> And its first accounting year ends on 2019-12-31 -> And it has a contact in United Kingdom named John Smith set to always charge VAT -> And the contact has organisation name 'Acme' -> And the company has the following bills: -> Given its VAT status changes to de-registered with an effective de-registration date of 2019-03-31 -> And the company filed its latest vat return -> And the company re-registered for VAT from 2019-11-01 on the Invoice basis, not on the FRS, with a pre-registration period of 6 months -> Then the company ledger entries for 818 (VAT reclaimed) are:

examples.description: Given a UK Limited Company which was started on 2019-01-01 -> And the company is Invoice accounting for VAT, not on the FRS -> And the current date is 2019-11-30 -> And it is VAT registered from 2019-01-01 -> And its first accounting year ends on 2019-12-31 -> And it has a contact in United Kingdom named John Smith set to always charge VAT -> And the contact has organisation name 'Acme' -> And the company has the following bills: -> Given its VAT status changes to de-registered with an effective de-registration date of 2019-03-31 -> And the company filed its latest vat return -> And the company re-registered for VAT from 2019-11-01 on the Invoice basis, not on the FRS, with a pre-registration period of 48 months -> Then the company ledger entries for 818 (VAT reclaimed) are:
examples.full_description: Pre-registration periods that overlap previous registrations First registration over 6 months before second registration, and pre-reg is set as 4 years. #we actually set the pre-reg to start the day after the de-registration date of the first registration Given a UK Limited Company which was started on 2019-01-01 -> And the company is Invoice accounting for VAT, not on the FRS -> And the current date is 2019-11-30 -> And it is VAT registered from 2019-01-01 -> And its first accounting year ends on 2019-12-31 -> And it has a contact in United Kingdom named John Smith set to always charge VAT -> And the contact has organisation name 'Acme' -> And the company has the following bills: -> Given its VAT status changes to de-registered with an effective de-registration date of 2019-03-31 -> And the company filed its latest vat return -> And the company re-registered for VAT from 2019-11-01 on the Invoice basis, not on the FRS, with a pre-registration period of 48 months -> Then the company ledger entries for 818 (VAT reclaimed) are:

examples.description: Given exchange rates of -> Given the pre-generated 2021 company using Invoice accounting for VAT, not on the FRS -> Given a sent USD invoice to Uncle Sam dated on 2020-01-01 -> And it has a line for 1 Hour of Awesomeness @ $1000.00 + 20% VAT -> Given a sent USD credit note to Uncle Sam dated on 2020-01-02 -> And the credit note has a line for 1 Hour of Awesomeness @ $1000.00 + 20% VAT -> And a credit note reconciliation is created for $1200.00 -> Then the credit note reconciliation should have ledger entries -> And the Accrual Ledger Entries on the invoice will be -> And the Accrual Ledger Entries on the credit note will be
examples.full_description: Credit note reconcillation Invoice and credit note are both in the same foreign currency Given exchange rates of -> Given the pre-generated 2021 company using Invoice accounting for VAT, not on the FRS -> Given a sent USD invoice to Uncle Sam dated on 2020-01-01 -> And it has a line for 1 Hour of Awesomeness @ $1000.00 + 20% VAT -> Given a sent USD credit note to Uncle Sam dated on 2020-01-02 -> And the credit note has a line for 1 Hour of Awesomeness @ $1000.00 + 20% VAT -> And a credit note reconciliation is created for $1200.00 -> Then the credit note reconciliation should have ledger entries -> And the Accrual Ledger Entries on the invoice will be -> And the Accrual Ledger Entries on the credit note will be
